bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: In 1994, the artist Frank Moore and arts writer David Hirsh formed the Archive Project to protect the legacies of artists who were being lost to the AIDS crisis. Moore and Hirsh were joined by Roberto Juarez, Sur Rodney (Sur), Eric Rhein, Geoff Hendricks, Ken Chu, and David Cabrera in this endeavor, and the group soon merged with Visual AIDS.

The founding principle of the Archive Project was to support any and all self-identified HIV positive artists, without adjudication. To make this possible, the project focused on creating and collecting photographic documentation of artist's work, rather than attempting to store and conserve the art objects themselves. Artists were solicited to join the archive through flyers, posters, and personal outreach. Volunteer photographers would visit artists in their homes or studios to document and catalog their artwork, providing the artist with a copy of the slides and depositing a copy into the Artist File collection. Artists (and the friends and families of deceased artists) also contributed press clippings, resumes, exhibition cards and other biographical materials to their artist files. The Artist File collection has continued to grow since its establishment in 1994, with an emphasis on digital photographs rather than slides since the late 2000s.

In the early 2000s, Visual AIDS produced several calendars featuring artwork by artists living with HIV, the Positively Art Calendar. Materials related to this competition are included in several artist files and consist of a combination of submission forms, images of artwork, and artist statement.

In addition to material donated by artists and estates, Artist Files include material related to Postcards from the Edge, a yearly Visual AIDS fundraiser. For this fundraiser, Visual AIDS solicits artwork from artists and any submission forms and unsold artworks are then added to Artist Files.

In 2014, Visual AIDS launched an online Artist Registry (visualaids.org/artists), which includes digitized images from the Artist File collection as well as images uploaded directly by artists and estates.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Artist Files collection includes personal papers and records pertaining to the lives and work of artists living with HIV and AIDS, as well as those who have passed. The collection primarily consists of photographic documentation of artwork (both physical and digital), exhibition materials, publications, ephemera, correspondence, and personal papers and photographs. The collection contains a small number of artworks on paper, primarily unsold contributions to Visual AIDS' Postcards from the Edge fundraiser.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is organized by artist name.

odd.head: General
odd.p: The Visual AIDS Artist Files collection documents HIV-positive artists. Recognizing the sensitivity of HIV disclosure, we work to confirm permission from artists and estates before publishing their name in this digital finding aid.
If you are an artist or the executor of an estate represented in this finding aid and would like to be removed, please email archive@visualaids.org.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This finding aid was prepared by Jacs Rodriguez in 2024. This finding aid was made possible in part by a grant from the Documentary Heritage Program of the New York State Archives, a program of the State Education Department.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: Materials in the Artist Files collection have been donated by artist members, estates, friends, and family members. Additional materials have been added by Visual AIDS staff.

Artists and executors are asked to sign a release from upon initial donation of materials. The donation dates listed in this finding aid are inferred from the date on the signed release form included in artist's folder.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: David was born in 1953 and raised in the Boston area. He was educated at the Massachusetts College of Art. David B. Abbott's work addressed contemporary political and social issues earning him the nickname of "social realist". Abbott's 30-year career includes exhibitions in Boston, New York, Key West, Miami, Fire Island, Long Beach and San Francisco.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: David Abbott first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 1998. They contain a CV, exhibition announcements, calendar submission materials, ephemera, and 35mm slides of his artwork. These materials are dated 1979-2015.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Norman Bradley Abercrombie was born in 1962 in Tampa, Florida. He attended Georgia State University for graphic design. He lived and worked in Atlanta, Georgia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Norman Bradley Abercrombie first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2004. They contain examples of design work, drawings, and a self-portrait. These materials are dated 2004.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Eric Abrams was born in 1960 in Oakland, California. His work includes acrylic on canvas, photo collage, and found object sculpture work. It has been exhibited in New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Eric Abrams first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2000. They contain images of artwork with descriptions, and 35mm slide documentation of art with accompanying image list. These materials are dated 1999-2000.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Szymon Adamczak was born in 1991. He is a dramaturg, writer, and performance artist. He lives in Amsterdam, the Netherlands, works for STUDIO theatregallery in Warsaw, Poland as dramaturg, and volunteers for HIV Vereniging, an organization for people living with HIV.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Szymon Adamczak include a zine dated 2018.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: George Alan is a Brazilian artist who worked in New York. He studied theater design at Parsons School of Design. He works primarily in oil, pastel, and acrylic on canvas.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: George Alan first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 1997. They contain correspondence, calendar submission materials, and 35mm slide documentation of artwork. These materials are dated 1997-1998.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Alex Aleixo was born in Brazil in 1952. He lived and worked in Los Angeles for 12 years. He held a bachelors degree in architecture from a university in Rio de Janeiro, but worked in the garment industry doing computer graphics for textiles and silkscreen.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Alex Aleixo first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2001. They contain a CV, exhibition announcements, an artist statement, exhibition programs, and 35mm slide documentation of his work. These materials are dated 2001-2007.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Carlos Alfonzo was born in Cuba in 1950. He received a degree in art from the Academia San Alejandro in 1973 and in art history from the University of Havana. He taught and exhibited in Cuba. He came to Miami during the Mariel boat lift in 1980 and lived and worked there. His work is in the permanent collection of the Miami-Dade Public Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Carlos Alfonzo were first donated to the Visual AIDS archive in 1998 by Sena Artigas. They contain a CV and 35mm slide documentation of art with accompanying image list. These materials are dated 1976-1991.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Ali was born in 1954 in Cuba and moved to Miami, becaming an established photo artist during his time in South Beach. He received a bachelor of fine arts from the Academy of Arts College of San Francisco and attended the School of Visual Arts in New York and Chicago.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ali first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2005. They contain photographic prints, correspondence, exhibition materials, ephemera, and 35mm slide documentation of art. These materials are dated 1990-2011.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Mark Allen was born in 1961 in Colorado and grew up in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma. He attended Southern Nazarene University and was an artist and visual merchandise designer. He died in 1993 in New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Mark Allen include his artist statement, memorial materials, personal photographs, and 35mm slide documentation of art. These materials are dated 1987-1990.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Edith Alvarez was born in 1964 in Belgium and lived and worked in New York. She received a degree in fashion design. Her artwork is primarily in painting and craft work.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Edith Alvarez first donated material to the Visual AIDS archive in 2004. They contain an artist's biography and an image list. These materials are dated 2004.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Marcelo Alves was born in 1970 in Washington, DC. He studied at Parsons School of Design, Montgomery College, and the School of Visual Arts. His work is primarily in painting and drawing and has been exhibited in New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Marcelo Alves first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2004. They consist of 35mm slide documentation of art. They are dated 1990-2004.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Rob Anderson was born in 1953. His work includes painting, drawing, and print, primarily in a realist style. In 1982, he created the iconic poster for the Gay Olympic Games (now called the Gay Games), which adapted classical Greek vase painting forms into a contemporary athletic symbol. He passed away in 2014.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Rob Anderson first donated materials to Visual AIDS archive in 2005. They include an exhibition catalog, press clippings, a CV, a CD with images of artwork, and image lists. These materials are dated from 2003-2005.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Stephen Andrews was born in 1956 in Sarnia, Ontario, Canada. His work deals with memory, identity, technology and their representations in various media including drawing, animation and painting. He has exhibited his work in Canada and internationally. He is represented in the collections of the National Gallery of Canada, the Art Gallery of Ontario, the Belkin Art Gallery, the Schwartz Collection, Harvard as well as many private collections.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Stephen Andrews first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 1998. They include images of artwork, CDs with images of artwork, exhibition materials, and press clippings. These materials are dated 1991-2009.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Patrick Angus was born in 1953 in North Hollywood, California and studied at Santa Barbara Community College, the Santa Barbara Art Institute, and the University of California, Santa Barbara. He moved to New York and worked as a security guard at the Museum of Modern Art where he was inspired to paint more. He created a large number of acrylic paintings of the inside of the Gaiety Theater, a gay male burlesque theater in Times Square, New York, and some of its dancers and customers in the 1980s. He passed away in 1992 in New York City.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Patrick Angus include periodicals, exhibition catalogs, and an image list. These materials are dated from 1979-2019.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Tonci Antunovic was born in 1975. He studied political science at the University of Zagreb in Croatia. His artwork was primarily in photography, installation, and digital art. His work has been exhibited in Croatia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tonci Antunovic first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2014. They contain printouts of artist's website. These items are dated from 2014.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Juan Arellano was born in 1964 in Bogota, Colombia. He studied at Columbia University, New York University, and the New School, and holds a degree in architecture. His work is primarily acrylic and oil on canvas, as well as etching.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Juan Arellano first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 1998. They contain exhibition announcements, Postcards from the Edge submission materials, and 35mm slide documentation of his work. These materials are dated from 1993-1998.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Steven Arnold was born in 1943. He received a BFA and MFA from San Francisco Art Institute. He was influential in shaping the countercultural psychedelic scene of San Francisco in the 1960s. He became Salvador Dali's protege and worked as a visionary filmmaker, photographer, painter, illustrator, set and costume designer, and assemblage artist. He passed away in 1994.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Steven Arnold include exhibition announcements and notes on the artist. These materials are dated 2015.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Jordan Arseneault was born in 1980. He is an active member of Montreal's queer performance scene. He is a drag performer, writer, meeting facilitator, and translator. His work addresses issues of queerness, gender, and social injustice.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Jordan Arsenault include one advertisement card.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Isaac Auguste was born in 1975 in Haiti. He was educated at Ecole nationale des arts and the Institut Michel Hair Design in Port-aux-Prince. He moved to the Bronx, New York and has worked as an artistic director as well as a freelance artist and make up artist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Isaac Auguste first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2012. They contain Postcards from the Edge submission materials, a CV, and a CD of artwork documentation. These materials are dated from 2012.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Dominick Avellino was born in 1944 in New York City. His work is primarily in oil painting. It has been exhibited in New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dominick Avellino first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 1997. His papers include correspondence, Postcard from the Edge submission materials, calendar submission materials, and photographs of his drawings and paintings. These materials are dated 1994-2002.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: azt was born in 1974, and lives and works in Bologna, Italy. He is a photographer primarily of male nudes. He has produced artists books and been published in contemporary art magazines and catalogs. He has exhibited in museums and private galleries across Europe and the United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to azt include Postcards from the Edge submission materials. These materials are dated 2017.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Mitchell Baker was born and raised in Manhattan. He studied at Parsons School of Design and worked in graphic design for many years. He left New York in 1995 to pursue painting. He now lives in Provincetown, Massachusetts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mitchell Baker first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2001. They contain his CV and an artist's biography. These materials are dated 2001.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Jürgen Baldiga was born in 1959. He moved to Berlin in 1979 and began working in poetry, music, film, and performance art. He began to work in photography in 1985 which he used to document his life and the loss of a "culture of possibility" during the time of inhumane AIDS policies. His work has been exhibited along with excerpts from 40 of his diaries in Berlin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Jürgen Baldiga include an exhibition announcement. This material is dated 2023.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Gregory Ball was born in 1971 in Albuquerque, New Mexico. His work includes painting, photography, sculpture, installation work, and wall design. His work has been exhibited in his own space.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The holdings of Gregory Ball were donated to Visual AIDS by Ball in 2005. They contain photographic prints, dated 2002.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Osvaldo Barrocal was born in Panama City, Panama and came to New York via Texas. He attended the State University of New York's Empire Studio Program for independent studies in art. He passed away in 1993 at age 29 in New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Osvaldo Barracol were first donated to the Visual AIDS archive by Claire McConaughy in 1998. It contains 35mm documentation of artwork. They are dated from 1988-1993.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Amos Beaida was born in 1960 in Auburn, California and lived in Weimar, California until 1978. He started drawing when he was in his late teens and early twenties. He lived in Oregon and Texas before settling in Mountain Home, Idaho and living there until his death in March of 2009.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Amos Beaida first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2004. It contains correspondence and 35mm slide documentation of artwork. They are dated 1982-2004.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Robert Beard was born in 1959 in Atlanta, Georgia. He studied at the University of Georgia, Athens and the School of Visual Arts. His art has been shown in various exhibitions around the United States and Europe.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Robert Beard first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 1998. They contain a curatorial planning notebook, correspondence, CVs, an artist statement, digital reproductions of artwork, exhibition announcements, ephemera, and 35mm slide documentation of artwork. They are dated from 1996-2001.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Charles Bell was born in 1935. His work is in American photorealist and hyperrealist large-scale still lifes. His work has appeared in various books and publications and is housed in collections at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Guggenheim, and the Hiroshima City Museum of Contemporary Art. He passed away in 1995.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Charles Bell include a catalog of artworks, book announcement, press materials, and 35mm slide documentation of art. These materials are dated 1991.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Thomas Belloff was born in 1962 in New Brunswick, New Jersey. He received fine arts training from the Newark School of Fine and Industrial Art as well as private instruction. His work includes paintings, linocuts, and sculpture.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Thomas Belloff first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 1998. They contain Postcards from the Edge submission materials, handwritten correspondence, ephemera, a CD, a piece of original art, and 35mm documentation of art. These materials are dated from 1989-2011.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Barton Lidicé Beneš was born in 1942 in Brentwood, New Jersey. He was educated at Pratt Institute and Top Art School D'avignon in France. His work was exhibited in numerous solo and group exhibitions across the United States and Europe. He passed away in 2012 in New York City.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Barton Lidicé Beneš first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 1997. They contain exhibition announcements, exhibition catalogs, photographic prints of artwork, a CV, periodicals, correspondence, zines, calendar submission materials, and 35mm slide documentation of his artworks. These materials are dated from 1992-2003.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Vernon E. Berg III, known as "Copy" for his close resemblance to his father, was born in Port Jefferson, New York, and attended the U.S. Naval Academy. He was the first Naval Academy alumnus to actively fight the policies against homosexuality in the services. After departing the Navy, he moved to New York and earned a master's degree in design from Pratt Institute in Brooklyn. His work includes painting, illustration, photography, and mixed media. He passed away in 1999 in New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Copy (Vernon E. Berg III) Berg first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 1997. They contain various exhibition announcements, postcards, Postcards from the Edge submission materials, correspondence, CVs, image lists, periodicals, 35mm slide documentation of artwork, and print-outs of artwork. These materials are dated 1990-1997.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Kermit Berg was born in 1951 in Indiana. He earned a bachelor's of art from the University of Indianapolis and studied graphic design in the graduate program there as well. He also studied digital arts at the School of the Art Institute in Chicago. His work is primarily in photography and has been exhibited numerous times in the US. He moved to Berlin in 1993.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Kermit Berg first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2004. They contain exhibition announcements, CDs with images of art, a wedding invitation, press clippings, image lists, photographic prints, and 35mm slide documentation of art. These materials are dated 2001-2008.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Michael Berube was born in 1957 in Endicott, NY. He obtained an associate's degree in commercial art and went on to study at SUNY Buffalo, majoring in painting. He moved to New York City to pursue a career as a performer and a painter. He was an adjunct professor at Hunter College and a curator. He passed away in 2024.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Michael Berube first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 1999. They contain exhibition announcements, Postcards from the Edge submission materials, a CD with images of artwork, periodicals, a CV, images lists, and 35mm slide documentation of artwork. These materials are dated 2000-2006.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Tom Bianchi was born in 1945 in the suburbs of Chicago. He graduated from Northwestern University School of Law and worked as a corporate attorney. He moved to New York and became an art collector and later an artist. He started as a painter and sculptor before turning his attention to photography. He lives and works in New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Tom Bianchi include a press clipping dated 1998.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Billy Bigs was born in 1947 in New Jersey. He is a self-taught artist. His work is primarily in collage, sculpture, and photography. His work has been exhibited privately by him as well as publicly in New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Billy Bigs first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2003. They contain a Postcards from the Edge submission, physical works of art, and correspondence. These materials are dated from 1997-2000.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Michael Binkley was born in 1954 in Lancaster, Pennsylvania. He studied at the Tyler School of Art in Philadelphia and Pratt Institute in New York. He has worked as an art director and a freelancer as well as a prolific painter in New York City.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Michael Binkley first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2000. They contain a resume, correspondence, ephemera, and 35mm slide documentation of art with related image list. These materials are dated from 1974-2000.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Raynes Birkbeck was born in 1956 in the Bronx and now lives and works in Manhattan, New York. He studied at the New School. He is a self-taught artist who paints, sculpts, draws, and writes poetry. His work has been exhibited in New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Raynes Birkbeck first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2001. They contain photocopies of art, an artist statement, correspondence, periodicals, exhibition brochures, a Postcards from the Edge submission, ephemera, and 35mm slide documentation of artwork with accompanying slide list. These materials are dated 2001-2020.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Robert Blanchon was born in 1965 in Boston. He studied at the Art Institute of Chicago. In 1990 he was among dozens of artists who created public billboards for the Art Against AIDS project in Chicago. His work is conceptual in nature and includes photography, illustration, mixed media, video, and xerox art. It has been exhibited in New York. He passed away in 1999 in Chicago.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Robert Blanchon first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 1998. They contain a CV, exhibition materials, press clippings, photocopies and CD documentation of photo and video work, materials related to catalogue raisonne released by Visual AIDS, ephemera, exhibition catalogs, periodicals, and 35mm slide documentation of art with accompanying image lists. These materials are dated from 1987-2010

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Mykki Blanco was born in 1986. They were a child actor who later gained fame as a noise rap poet, publishing a book and then starting a video art project that kickstarted his online following. They continue to create art as a nonbinary post-homo-hop musical artist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Mykki Blanco include a periodical dated 2020.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Raymond Bordeaux was born in 1962 in Omaha, Nebraska. He was educated at the University of Minnesota. He moved to California in his adult life and continued to create photographic work. He passed away in 2023 in California.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Raymond Bordeaux first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2002. They contain photographs and prints, a photography book, exhibition announcements, correspondence, CD documentation of art, and 35mm slide documentation of art with accompanying image lists. These materials are dated 1997-2005.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Jorge Bordello was born in 1989 in Tlaxcala, Mexico. He studied at the National Photo Library System and the Image Center at Mexico City. His artwork includes sculpture, photography, installation, and video work. His video work has been part of various international festivals.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Jorge Bordello include photographic prints of artwork and a sketchbook with notes related to a video commissioned by Visual AIDS.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Freddy Borges was born in 1955 in Caracas, Venezuela. He studied civil engineering at the Universidad Central de Venezuela and later explored the field of plastic arts. He also studied ceramics in Caracas. He moved to New York City after receiving a scholarship from the Art Students League. His art spans disciplines and has been exhibited in various exhibitions across the US and South America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Freddy Borges first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 1999. They contain exhibition announcements, artist's statements, a Postcards from the Edge submission, exhibition flyers, a calendar submission, and 35mm slide documentation of art with accompanying image lists. These materials are dated 1992-2000.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Frank Boros was born in 1943 in Bridgeport, Connecticut. He received his bachelor's of art from University of Connecticut, and a masters of fine art from Yale University. He moved to New York and exhibited art there and in the surrounding states for many years. He passed away in 2017 in New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Frank Boros first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2013. They include prints and photocopies of artwork, a CV, personal ephemera, and exhibition announcements. These materials are dated from 2000-2004.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Michael Boroskey was born in 1962 in Fairfield, Connecticut. He received a BFA in printmaking from the Philadelphia University of the Arts. His art was exhibited across the United States, particularly in New York, Pennsylvania, and Florida. He passed away in 2012 in Florida.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Michael Boroskey first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2001. They contain artist statements, photocopies of art, press clippings, exhibition announcements, a zine, correspondence, a CD with art, a Postcards from the Edge submission, ephemera, and 35mm slide documentation of art with accompanying slide list. These materials are dated from 1997-2001.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Angel Borrero was born in 1950 in Puerto Rico. He received a BFA from Parsons School of Design in New York in 1977. He worked primarily in mixed media painting and drawing. He also worked in film producing. He passed away in 1994.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Angel Borrero were first donated to the Visual AIDS archive by Sur Rodney (Sur) in 1997. They contain a CV, a biography, correspondence, and 35mm slide documentation of art. These materials are dated 1990-1994.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: George Box was born in 1942 in Waterbury, Connecticut. He studied at the School of Visual Arts, New York University, and the Art Students League. He specialized in mixed media sculpture and painting and exhibited in New York and Florida. He lives in Florida.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: George Box first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2004. They contain a resume, artist statements, exhibition materials, photocopies of press clippings, correspondence, and 35mm slide documentation of art with accompanying image log. These materials are dated 1997-2001.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Bruce Wesley Boyce was born in 1942 in Saratoga Springs, New York. He studied at the Brooklyn Museum Art School and the School of Visual Arts. His art was exhibited primarily in New York. He passed away in 2018 in New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bruce Wesley Boyce first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 1999. They contain a resume, photocopies of art, press clippings, artist statements, correspondence, Postcards from the Edge submission materials, exhibition announcements, ephemera, and 35mm slide documentation of art with accompanying image list. These materials are dated 1990-1999.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Bern Boyle was born in 1951 in Philadelphia. He went to college there before moving to San Francisco and later New York City. He documented gay life and his activism through photography and postcard artworks and also worked in film production. He passed away in 1992 in New York City.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Bern Boyle were first donated to the Visual AIDS archive by Sur Rodney (Sur) in 1997. They contain correspondence, interviews, press clippings, postcard art prints, a Photomaton catalog, 35mm slide documentation of art with accompanying image log. These materials are dated 1986-1992.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Joe Brainard was born in 1942 in Arkansas and spent his childhood in Tulsa, Oklahoma. He studied at the Dayton Art Institute and then moved to New York City. He worked with miniatures, drawing, painting, collage, and designing book and album covers as well as theatrical sets and costumes. He passed away in 1994 in New York City.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Joe Brainard were first donated to the Visual AIDS archive in 1997. They included photocopies of press clippings, a CV, exhibition announcements, publication announcements, periodicals, and 35mm slide documentation of work with accompanying image list. These materials are dated 1964-2012.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Bradford Branch was born in 1952 in Brooklyn, New York. He attended an arts high school in Newark, New Jersey and later the Fashion Institute of Technology in New York. He worked in the garment industry as illustrator, assistant designer, pattern maker, and designer. He also worked under a master printmaker and became a printmaker, working on book covers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bradford Branch first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 1998. They include artist biographies, a resume, letters of recommendation, exhibition flyers, Postcards from the Edge submissions, exhibition press release, periodicals, photocopies of art, book cover previews, and 35mm slide documentation of art with accompanying image list. These materials are dated 1992-2008.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: John Eric Broaddus was born in 1943 in Detroit, Michigan, but spent the majority of his years in New York City after moving there in his twenties. He decorated store windows for work while making books and costumes as his passion. He passed away in 1990 in New York City.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to John Eric Broaddus were first donated to the Visual AIDS archive by Geoffrey Hendricks in 1997. They contain artist statements, correspondence, press clippings, photocopies of art, exhibition catalogs, a CD with images of art, and 35mm slide documentation of art. These materials are dated 1974-2005.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Patrick Brown was born in 1953 in East St Louis, Illinois. He studied at Jefferson College in Jefferson County, Missouri, Hendrix College in Conway, Arkansas, and the University of Memphis. He concentrated on painting and was the creative director of a UK-based company. Patrick currently lives and works in Escondido, California and is a member of the Escondido Arts Partnership and Municipal Gallery.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Patrick Brown first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2011. These materials contain a photo of the artist and a Postcards from the Edge submission. These materials are dated 2012.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Rodney Brown was born in 1954 in Washington, DC. A gifted collagist, his work has been shown in galleries in New York City and Ohio. He is a social worker by profession.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Rodney Brown first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 1997. They contain a CV, a biography, correspondence, a print of artwork, a CD with art, and 35mm documentation of art. These materials are dated 1995-1997.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Roger Brown was born in 1941 and raised in Hamilton and Opelika, Alabama. He studied at the American Academy of Art and earned two degrees at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago. He worked in painting, printmaking, sculpture, and painted objects. He and his contemporaries became known as Chicago Imagists. His art was exhibited extensively and is housed in various important museum collections. His art collection and home have been preserved in their original order by the School of the Art Institute of Chicago as the Roger Brown Study Collection. It is a house museum open to the public filled with what Brown caled his "Artists' Museum of Chicago". He passed away in 1997.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Roger Brown include photographs, exhibition announcements, an artist's biography, CVs, correspondence, catalog of artworks, and press clippings. These materials are dated 2012-2015.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Jack Brusca was born in 1936 in New York City and attended graduate school at the School of Visual Arts. He exhibited widely in the United States and Brazil and his art was collected by many large institutions. He passed away in 1993 in Manhattan.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Jack Brusca were first donated to the Visual AIDS archive by Bill Brusca in 1997. They contain a CV, artist's biography, correspondence, exhibition catalogs, exhibition announcements, press clippings, photographs, ephemera, and 35mm slide documentation of artwork. These materials are dated 1986-2021.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Loreen Bryant was born in 1949 in New York. She attended Art and Design high school and went on to take subsequent art classes elsewhere. She works primarily in drawing. Her art has been shown in various exhibits around New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Loreen Bryant first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2005. They contain CDs with images of art, Postcards from the Edge submission materials, exhibition announcements, and 35mm slide documentation of art with accompanying image list. These materials are dated 2003-2011.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Steven Dwayne Bryk was born in 1958 in Beausejour, Manitoba. He studied at the University of Manitoba, the University of Toronto, and the California Coast University, his highest degree being a doctorate of psychology. He has worked as a teacher for many years and his art is primarily in photography.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Steven Dwayne Bryk first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2007. They contain a CD with images of art, materials related to a Postcards from the Edge submission, a CV, an image list, exhibition promotional materials, press release, correspondence, and print-outs of archive website crediting artist's work. These materials are dated 1998-2007.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Brian Buczak was born in Detroit in 1954. He received a BFA from the Center for Creative Studies. He moved to New York City in 1975 to continue painting. Brian's art expanded to include paintings, drawing, writings, publishing, artist's books, collaborations, Fluxus projects, film, performance and more. His work has been exhibited internationally, including New York, Detroit, Canada, Italy, and Iceland. Brian passed away in 1987 in New York City.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Brian Buczak were first donated to the Visual AIDS archive by Geoffrey Hendricks in 1997. They contain a CD with images of art, exhibition announcements, a Postcards from the Edge submission, artist biography, a CV, correspondence, exhibition materials, image lists, press clippings, exhibition catalogs, and photocopies of press clippings, and 35mm slide documentation of art with accompanying image lists. These materials are dated 1982-2010.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Richard Burrowes was born in 1990 in Long Island, New York. He studied illustration and photography at Pratt Institute. He is a freelance photographer in New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Richard Burrowes first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2012. They contain CDs with images of his art. These materials are dated 2009.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Scott Burton was born in 1939 in Greensboro, Alabama. He received a BA from Columbia University and an MA from New York University. He was a sculptor who worked in the tradition of utilitarian modernism. His work has been commissioned and exhibited internationally, and remains in collections across the US. He passed away in 1989.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Scott Burton donated to the Visual AIDS archive contain correspondence, a CV, press clippings, and 35mm slide documentation of art. These materials are dated 1977-1998.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Ira Byelick was born in 1976 in Louisville, Kentucky. He began music studies early in life and studied at the University of Louisville School of Music. In 2006, he started drawing and painting, primarily watercolor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ira Byelick first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2007. They include CDs with images of art, a CV, a biography, correspondence, and 35mm slide documentation of art with accompanying image list. These materials are dated 2007-2010.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Jerome Caja was born in 1958 in Cleveland, Ohio. He received his MFA in ceramics from the San Francisco Art Institute. He painted miniatures with nail polish, glitter, make-up, lipstick, and eyeliner. His canvases included pistachio shells, lockets, bottle caps, and other scraps. His art was exhibited primarily in California and Ohio. His papers are held at the Smithsonian Archives of American Art. He passed away in 1995.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Jerome Caja were first donated to the Visual AIDS archive in 2007. This collection inculdes a CV. The material is dated 2007.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Rene Capone was born in 1978 in Niskayuna, New York. He attended Parsons School of Design before moving to San Francisco where he is still based. Private collectors of Capone's work can be found in the United States of America, Canada, Sweden, England, France, Japan, and the Netherlands. He self published the graphic novel 'The Legend of Hedgehog Boy' in 2011, a story about a boy who goes into the woods to find his identity.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Rene Capone first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2002. They contain exhibition announcements, postcards of art, correspondence, printouts of art, Postcards from the Edge submission materials, ephemera, periodicals, artist statements, printouts of digital content, photographic prints, press clippings, comic books, and 35mm slide documentation of art with accompanying image lists. These materials are dated 2000-2010.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Aracelis Cardenas was born in 1951 in Santiago, Dominican Republic. He studied architecture at the Universidad Autonoma de Santo Domingo. His art is primarily acrylic paintings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Aracelis Cardenas first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2012. They contain CDs with images of artwork, image logs, artwork print outs, and ephemera. These materials are dated 2004-2012.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Valerie Caris Blitz was born in 1957 in Boston, Massachusetts. Her artwork involved painting, performance art, acting, modeling, and creation of other art objects. She studied in New York City, Germany, and Boston. The focus of her artwork shifted to HIV and AIDS in 1989. She passed away in 2009.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Valerie Caris Blitz first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 1997. They contain photographs of art, a biography, art descriptions, a CV, exhibition announcement, photocopies of press clippings, printouts of digital content, periodicals, and 35mm slide documentation of art with accompanying image list. These materials are dated 1993-2000.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Luis Carle was born in 1962 in San Juan, Puerto Rico. He moved to New York City in 1984 to study photography at Parsons School of Design. He worked for various magazines, advertising campaigns, and documentaries as well as being shown in galleries. His work is part of the permanent collection of the Leslie Lohman Museum of Art in New York City.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Luis Carle first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 1997. They contain exhibition announcements, exhibition catalogs, CVs, press releases, photocopies of press clippings, photographic prints of artwork, a CD with images of art, periodicals, and 35mm slide documentation of art with accompanying image list. These materials are dated 1993-2009.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Joel Carlson was born in 1957 in Nebraska. He studied advertising design at Boise State University before moving to Hawai'i in 1983. There he paints watercolors inspired by the natural world.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Joel Carlson first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2003. They contain postcards of artwork, CDs with images of artwork, a Postcards from the Edge submission, correspondence, and 35mm slide documentation of art with accompanying image list. These materials are dated 1990-2006.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Curtis Carman was born in 1959 in Massachusetts. He received a BFA and MFA from Hunter College. His work includes sculpture, performance, and photography. He lives and works in New York City.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Curtis Carman first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2005. They contain exhibition announcements, a Postcards from the Edge submission, CVs, an artist bio, an artist's statement, printouts of digital content, press clippings, periodicals, copies of visual and written work, CDs with artwork, exhibition catalogs, and 35mm slide documentation of art with accompanying image list. These materials are dated 2001-2014.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Eddie Carreras was born in 1953 in the Bronx, New York. His work includes watercolor, acrylics, and drawings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Eddie Carreras first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 1999. They include correspondence, an artist bio, and artwork on cardboard. These materials are dated 1999.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Mark Carter was born in 1954 in Queens, New York. He received his GED and a college degree and had a career in nursing. After an accident resulted in his yearlong hospitalization he started to make art. He passed away in 2005.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mark Carter first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 1998. They contain exhibition announcements, correspondences, a memorial program, artist bios, CVs, artist's statement, photocopies of press clippings, artwork, photocopies of artwork, photographs of artwork, periodicals, exhibition catalog, and 35mm slide documentation of art with accompanying image lists. These materials are dated 1996-2005.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Gregg Cassin was born in 1958 in New York. Gregg creates his art using found materials such as discarded/orphaned vintage photographs, old books, sacred imagery, sewing notions, and more. He lives between San Francisco and Sag Harbor, Long Island.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Gregg Cassin first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2002. They contain exhibition announcements, a CD with images of art, correspondence, ephemera, artist's statements and biography, reviews, press clippings, photocopies of press clippings, image lists, periodicals, and 35mm slide documentation of art. These materials are dated 1999-2012.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Niccolo Cataldi was born in 1952 in San Pedro de Macoris, Dominican Republic. Educated at la Escuela de Diseno in the Dominican Republic and Parson's School of Design in New York, he now resides in New York City. Cataldi is a sculptor and painter and has been exhibited widely in New York and the Dominican Republic.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Niccolo Cataldi first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 1998. They contain exhibition announcements, postcards of artwork, correspondence, ephemera, exhibition catalogs, Postcards from the Edge submission materials, photocopies of collages, publications, CVs, photocopies of press clippings, CDs with images of art, periodicals, and 35mm slide documentation of art with accompanying image lists. These materials are dated 1997-2014.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Feliciano Centurion was born in 1962 in San Ignacio de las Misiones, Paraguay. He studied visual arts at the Escuela Nacional de Bellas Artes "Prilidiano Pueyrredon" in Argentina. His work includes painting, mixed media, and fiber arts and has been exhibited in Argentina and the US. He passed away in 1996.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Feliciano Centurion include an exhibition program. This material is dated 2020.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Walt Cessna was born in 1964. He was an artist, photographer, and author, as well as an editor, publisher, and curator. He passed away in 2017 in New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Walt Cessna include a periodical dated 2016.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Peter Cherone was born in 1956 in Patterson, New Jersey. Cherone was an artist and activist. He graduated from Pratt Institute with an MFA in Painting. He exhibited his work in New York, New Jersey, and Massachusetts. He died in 2010.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Peter Cherone first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 1997. They contain exhibition announcements, artist statements, correspondence, CVs, photocopies of press clippings, calendar submission materials, photographic prints, Postcards from the Edge submission materials, and 35mm slide documentation with accompanying image lists. These materials are dated 1991-2003.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: H. Alan Cheung was born in 1954 in Shanghai, China. He studied at Taiwan Normal University and Otis Art Institute. His work was mixed media on paper and canvas and was shown in New York, California, and Taiwan. He passed away in 2003.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: H Alan Cheung first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 1998. They contain exhibition catalogs, CVs, an installation mock-up, and 35mm slide documentation of art. These materials are dated 1990-1998.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Paul Chisholm was born in 1983 in Canterbury, UK. He received a BA from Nottingham Trent University. Chisholm's practice has been featured on The BBC, The Daily Star, Metro Newspaper, Attitude magazine and more. He lives between Bletchingley in Surrey & Amsterdam, Holland.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Paul Chisholm first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2010. They contain correspondence, a Postcards from the Edge submission, an artist's statement, CVs, and 35mm slide documentation of artwork with accompanying image list. These materials are dated 2009-2011.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Vincent Cianni was born in 1952 in Scranton, Pennsylvania. He holds an MFA in Photography from SUNY New Paltz and teaches at Parsons, the New School for Design in New York City. He is photographing Newburgh, New York where he currently lives using traditional, analog photographic materials and cameras.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Vincent Cianni first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2002. They contain exhibition announcements, Postcards from the Edge submissions, ephemera, art periodicals, CVs, artist biographies, interview materials, exhibition materials, artist's statements, printouts of digital content, photocopies of periodicals, photographic prints, and 35mm slide documentation of artwork with accompanying image list. These materials are dated 2001-2015.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Craig Coleman was born in 1961 in San Jose, California. He was a prominent figure in the New York downtown scene in the 80s. He moved to Miami and became involved with drag performance. He passed away in 1994 in Miami.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Craig Coleman were first donated to the Visual AIDS archive in 1998. They contain a CD with images of art, correspondence, a CV, an artist's biography, photographic documentation of artwork, and a 35mm slide of artwork. These materials are dated 1983-1998.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Michael K Colgan was born in 1958 in Coronado, California. He graduated from George Mason University, in Fairfax County, Virginia, with a bachelor of arts degree. He worked in advertising and graphic design for many years. His work was exhibited across the country. He passed away in 1993.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Michael K Colgan were first donated to the Visual AIDS archive by James Colgan in 1999. They contain an artist biography, correspondence, calendar submission materials, press clippings, lists of artworks, a CV, copies of press clippings, and 35mm slide documentation of artworks with accompanying image list. These materials are dated 1981-2001.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Ms Colombia (born Oswaldo Gomez) was born in 1954 in Medellin, Colombia. She moved to New York in the 1970s and was a colorful performance artist based in Jackson Heights, Queens. She received a bachelor's degree in Engineering and a master's in law from York University. She entertained crowds with colorful outfits based on her Colombian heritage. She was known as the Queen of Riis Park and the Queen of Queens. She passed away in 2018.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Ms Colombia include an exhibition announcement. This material is dated 2019.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Shirlene Cooper is an HIV activist from Brooklyn, New York. She started and runs the Women's Empowerment Art Therapy Group with Visual AIDS. She is an advocate for women living with HIV and is the first African American woman living with HIV to sit on New York City Council's HIV/AIDS Service Administrations Advisory Board. She has traveled to 46 states and 31 countries with her activism. She lives in Brooklyn, New York.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Materials pertaining to Shirlene Cooper include a periodical and photographic prints. These materials are dated 2021-2022.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Carlos Cordero was born in 1975 in the Dominican Republic. He studied art at SUNY Purchase where he discovered printmaking. His work has been exhibited widely in both solo and group exhibitions. Carlos now lives and works in his studio in Coney Island, New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Carlos Cordero first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2014. They contain grant materials and Postcards from the Edge submission materials. These items are dated 2014-2022.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Harold Cortes was born in 1958 in Cali, Colombia. He studied jewelry design and designed jewelry for Broadway shows and other productions in New York. He focused his full attention on painting and worked on several mural works with his partner, Gregory Maskwa. He also painted sets for Broadway. He was awarded a plaque for his art for the Presidential Proclamation for World AIDS Day in 1994. He passed away in 1996.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Harold Cortes include memorial materials, correspondence, an artist's biography, artist's statements, and 35mm slide documentation of art. These materials are dated 1996-2000.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: José Luis Cortés was born in 1962 in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania to Puerto Rican parents. They moved to Puerto Rico where he lived until the age of 28, when he moved to New York City. His artistic career took off more when he began producing work inspired by the 1990s New York City gay scene. His work has been exhibited in galleries and museums in the US and internationally. He lives and works in Puerto Rico.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Jose Luis Cortes first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 1997. They contain exhibition announcements, correspondence, exhibition catalogs, photographic prints, Postcards from the Edge submission materials, exhibition promotional materials, photocopies of press clippings, CVs, and periodicals. These materials are dated 1994-2007.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Bob Corti was born in 1951 in New York. He received a BFA from Queens College and an MFA in photography and painting from Boston University. He moved to San Francisco where he was an artist in residence, a teacher, and where his art was exhibited widely.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bob Corti first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 1998. They contain exhibition announcements, a CV, periodicals, calendar submission materials, correspondence, photographs, an artist's statement, and 35mm slide documentation of art with accompanying image list. These materials are dated 1996-2001.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Steven Cortiella was born in 1957 in Brooklyn, New York. He started creating art as a child, and has been a designer and in health care for most of his working life. He lives in Brooklyn.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Steven Cortiella first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2001. They contain Postcards from the Edge submission materials, correspondence, photographs of artwork, periodicals, and 35mm slide documentation of art with accompanying image list. These materials are dated 1999-2002.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Harold Cousar was born in 1951 in Brooklyn, New York. He studied at The Washington Business Institute.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Harold Cousar first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2004. They contain photocopies of drawings and photographs. These materials are dated 2004.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Max Coyer was born in 1954 in Hartford, Connecticut. He studied poetry at Trinity College in Hartford, Connecticut, before moving to New York City in 1980 to pursue visual arts. He worked primarily in painting, blnding both academic and modernist art movements. His work has been exhibited in New York as well as in Baltimore and Los Angeles. He passed away in 1988.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Max Coyer were donated to the Visual AIDS archive by Paula Pierce in 2023. They contain exhibition announcements, exhibition catalogs, press releases, and ephemera. These materials are dated 1985-1993.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Peter Cramer was born in 1957. He is the co-founder, artistic, and administrative director of Le Petit Versailles community garden in the East Village. He is known for cross-disciplinary multimedia work including experimental film, documentary, and diaristic approach. His work also includes photography, installation, and performance. With his longstanding partner and collaborator Jack Waters he co-established Allied Productions Inc., a non-profit arts umbrella, in 1981. They also served as directors of ABC No Rio alternative art collective from 1983 to 1990. His work has been exhibited widely in the US and internationally. He lives in New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Peter Cramer include Postcards from the Edge submission materials, a photo book, a CD with images of art, exhibition program, and a publication. These materials are dated 2008-2019.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Bruce Cratsley was born in 1944 in Canton, New York. He studied in Esslingen, West Germany, as well as at Swarthmore College, the University of Pennsylvania, and the New School. He worked in galleries and as a photographer. His photographs are held in the Brooklyn Museum, the New York Public Library, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Boston Museum of Fine Arts, and the Bibliotheque National in Paris. He passed away in 1998.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Bruce Cratsley were first donated to the Visual AIDS archive in 1999 by Sarah Morthland. They contain exhibition announcements, exhibition catalogs, artist's statements, artist's biography, correspondence, photocopies of press clippings, press releases, periodicals, and 35mm slide documentation of art. These materials are dated 1976-1997.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Brian Crede was born in 1952 in New York City. He graduated from Kent State University with a degree in industrial design and a minor in copper enameling. He works with paper and three-dimensional art. He moved to Fort Lauderdale in 2014. His artwork is in private collections around the US and France.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Brian Crede first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2003. They contain CDs with images of art, exhibition announcements, CVs, artist's statements, correspondence, printouts of art, printouts of digital content, periodicals, and 35mm slide documentation of art with accompanying image lists. These materials are dated 1998-2012.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Lucretia Crichlow was born in 1950 in the Bronx. She took night classes at the Fashion Institute of Technology while attending community college before becoming a full time student there. She worked for buying offices at fashion companies, and later for designers. She also did freelance fashion illustration. Her work is illustration on paper. She passed away in 1997.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Lucretia Crichlow were first donated to the Visual AIDS archive in 1998 by Loretta White. They contain 35mm slide documentation of art with accompanying labels. These materials are dated 1990-1994.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Preston Cros was born in 1970 in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. He is a self-taught artist whose work is primarily in photography.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Preston Cros first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2009. They contain a CD with images of artwork with accompanying image list. These materials are dated 2009.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Ben Cuevas was born in 1987 in Southern California. He received a BA in mixed media, installation, and photography at Hampshire College. He works primarily in textiles. It has been exhibited in Los Angeles and New York, and has also been featured in several books and publications.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Ben Cuevas include an exhibition program and periodicals. These materials are dated 2014-2016.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: William Cullum was born in 1958 in San Diego, California. He primarily produced paintings and works on paper. After spending some time incarcerated, he started a blog about that time and his experience as an artist afterwards. He passed away in 2020 in New York City.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: William Cullum first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 1994. They contain exhibition announcements, correspondence, photocopies of press clippings, various image lists, ephemera, and 35mm slide documentation of artwork with accompanying image lists. These materials are dated 1994-1999.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Vincent D'Arata studied various arts at the Culinary Institute of America, in Hyde Park, New York, Miami Dade College, St. Peters University in Jersey City, New Jersey, and The New School in New York. His work is primarily in painting, sculpture, and digital collage. It has been exhibited in New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Vincent D'Arata first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2009. They contain CDs with images of art, exhibition announcements, and grant application materials. These materials are dated 2006-2011.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: David Cannon Dashiell was born in 1952 in Tokyo, Japan. He received both a BFA and MFA from Cal Arts and worked there with John Baldessari. His work was exhibited extensively in California and New York, as well as other places around the country. His works are in the San Francisco MOMA, the University Art Museum Berkeley, the Whitney Museum of American Art, as well as private collections. He passed away in 1993 in San Francisco.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to David Cannon Dashiell were first donated to the Visual AIDS archive in 2007 by Sono Osato. They contain a CV, a bibliography, a posthumous biography, correspondence, exhibition materials, photocopies of press clippings and periodicals, a portfolio, a CD with images and a video, small printouts of "Queer Mysteries", posthumous Postcards from the Edge submission materials, exhibition announcements, exhibition catalogs, publications, and 35mm slide documentation of art. These materials are dated 1986-2005.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Patrick de Castro was born in Haiti. He studied interior design at Pratt Institute before moving to Miami. His work includes painting, collage, and mixed media.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Patrick De Castro include Postcards from the Edge submission materials.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Joe De Hoyos was born in 1962 in Houston, Texas. He attended the University of Houston majoring in graphic communications. He started to work with collage and moved to New York City in 1993 and maintained a studio in his living space. He currently lives in Palm Springs, California.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Joe De Hoyos first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 1997. They contain exhibition announcements, correspondence, CVs, an artist's bio, calendar submission materials, a newsletter, photocopies of artwork, periodicals, ephemera, CDs with images of artwork, and 35mm slide documentation of art with accompanying image lists. These materials are dated 1987-2003.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Jason Deneault was born in 1948 in Hanover, New Hampshire. Educated at Emerson College in Boston, Massachusetts, he also was trained in massage therapy and professional dance. His work with collage has been exhibited primarily in Massachusetts and New York. He lives in Cambridge, Massachusetts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Jason Deneault first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 1997. They contain exhibition announcements, Postcards from the Edge submission materials, artist's statements, CVs, calendar submission materials, correspondence, a photocopy of an artwork, and 35mm slide documentation of art with accompanying image list. These materials are dated 1986-2004.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Jimmy De Sana was born in 1949 and grew up in suburban Atlanta, Georgia. He graduated from Georgia State University in 1972 where he started pursuing photography. He moved to New York shortly after graduating college. He was a key figure in the East Village punk art scene of the 1970s and 1980s and photographed prominent creatives for album covers and alternative publications. William S. Burroughs wrote the introduction to his collection of photographs Submission which was self-published in 1980. He passed away in 1990.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Jimmy DeSana were first donated to the Visual AIDS archive in 1998 by Laurie Simmons. They contain exhibition announcements, a CV, a page from an exhibition catalog, a press clipping, and 35mm slide documentation of art. These materials are dated 1977-2010.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Dan Diamond grew up in Michigan and has been painting since adolescence. His work is primarily in abstract painting.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Dan Diamond include correspondence, a photocopy of artwork, and 35mm slide documentation of art. These materials are dated 1994-2000.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Angelho Diaz was born in 1966 in Havana, Cuba. As a child he took classes in painting, acting, vocal ensemble, instrumental groups, theatre, and others. After studying internationally, he returned to Havana to become a professional pianist. His visual art is a combination of painting, photography, and collage.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Angelho Diaz first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2019. They include an artist's biography, and printouts of artwork. These materials are dated 2017-2019.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Francisco Diaz was born in 1950 in Puerto Rico and raised in New York. He became a street artist to support his family. His art includes crafts, building wooden houses, ships, kitchen decorations, greeting cards, and works on paper.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Francisco Diaz first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 1998. They contain an artist's biography. These materials are dated 1998.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Gustavo Diaz was born in 1973. His work includes painting, illustration, collage, and multimedia work.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Gustavo Diaz include Postcards from the Edge submission materials. These materials are dated 2020.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: George Dinhaupt was born in 1955 in Los Angeles, California. He works primarily in portraiture. It has been exhibited primarily in New York and California.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: George Dinhaupt first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2011. They contain Postcard from the Edge submission materials, a CD with images of artwork, exhibition announcements, CVs, ephemera, and an artist's statement. These materials are dated 2011-2019.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Scott DiStefano was born in 1963 in Omaha, Nebraska. He studied graphic design and art. His work is primarily painting and photography and has been exhibited in New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Scott DiStefano first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2003. They include a printout of artwork dated 2003.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: William Donovan was born in 1953 in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. He studied at the Fashion Institute of Technology and the School of Visual Arts in New York City. His work has been exhibited in New York. His work incorporates various mediums such as oil, wax, acrylic, pencil, ink, thread, sand, and collage to wood, canvas, or paper.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: William Donovan first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2001. They contain Postcards from the Edge submission materials, exhibition announcements, an artist's statement, a CV, photocopies of press clippings, periodicals, and 35mm slide documentation of artwork. These materials are dated 1999-2007.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: durkART was born in 1960 in Chicago, Illinois and lives in Orlando. His paintings are based on joy and his experiences in the 1970s and 80s. His work has been exhibited in several galleries in the Orlando area.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: durkART first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2006. They contain exhibition announcements, correspondence, ephemera, artist's biography and CV, artwork on paper, and 35mm slide documentation of art. These materials are dated 2006-2021.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Chloe Dzubilo was born in 1960 in Middletown, Connecticut. She moved to New York in 1982 where she briefly worked at Studio 54 before becoming the art director at the magazine East Village Eye. She was an artist, musician, model, and longtime activist for civil rights and healthcare rights for people with HIV, the trans community, and drug users. She passed away in 2011 in New York City.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Chloe Dzubilo first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2011. They contain CDs with images of artwork, original artwork on paper, Postcards from the Edge submission materials, correspondence, zines, exhibition announcements, exhibition materials, artist's biography, memorial program and announcement, printout of digital content, and periodicals. These materials are dated 2004-2014.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Larry Eades was born in 1953 in Tarrytown, New York. He works in photography and painting.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Larry Eades first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 1997. They contain CDs with images of artwork, exhibition announcements, correspondence, artist's statement, calendar submission materials, photographic prints, photo proof sheets, and 35mm slide documentation of art with accompanying image list. These materials are dated 1992-2013.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Brent Nicholson Earle was born in 1951 in in Niagara Falls, New York. He is an artist and an early activist, notable for his long-distance runs to raise money for AIDS service organizations in the effort to promote AIDS awareness. Earle worked in New York City as an actor, writer, stage manager, lecturer, archivist, photographer, optical designer, curator, and art gallery administrator.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Brent Nicholson Earle first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 1998. They contain a CV, an artist's statement, artist biographies, an installation proposal, correspondence, calendar submission materials, and 35mm slide documentation of art with accompanying image list. These materials are dated 1986-2005.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Sean Earley was born in 1953 and resided mostly in Texas. In addition to his fine art, mostly oil on canvas, his career was as a commercial illustrator. His work was exhibited in Texas and New York. He passed away in 1992.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Sean Earley were first donated to the Visual AIDS archive in 1998 by Paul Bridgewater. They contain a CD with images of artwork, exhibition announcements, CVs, photocopies of press clippings, gallery materials, photographic print of artwork, a periodical, image lists, and 35mm slide documentation of art. These materials are dated 1984-1992.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Per Eidspjeld was born in 1960 in Asker, Norway. He works in photography, video, installation, and mixed media.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Per Eidspjeld first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 1999. They contain Postcards from the Edge submission materials, and 35mm slide documentation of art. These materials are dated 1991-2012.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Ed Eisenberg was born in 1951. He was involved in public art activism beginning with Political Art Documentation and Distribution and was also a core member of the artist collective REPOhistory. He passed away in 1997.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Material pertaining to Ed Eisenberg were first donated to the Visual AIDS archive in 2000. They contain exhibition announcements, exhibition catalogs, postcards, press clippings, printouts of art, photocopies of journal articles, periodicals, a CD, CVs, memorial biography, and 35mm slide documentation of art. These materials are dated 1989-2004.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Garland Eliason-French was born in 1942 in Peoria, Illinois. She attended Sarah Lawrence College in Bronxvillle, New York, and received a BFA from Bradley University, and an MFA from the Art Institute of Chicago. She was a prolific artist of various media. She passed away in 1996.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Garland Eliason-French were first donated to the Visual AIDS archive in 1994 by William P French Jr. Additional materials were donated in 2019 by Laura Eliason. They contain correspondence, personal journals, personal photographs, exhibition catalogs, an obituary, periodicals, press clippings, address book contents, photographs of art, ephemera, and 35mm slide documentation of art. These materials are dated 1965-1997.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: eljay was born in 1961 in Bay Shore, New York. He studied at Polytechnic Institute of New York. His work is primarily photography and has been exhibited in New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: eljay first donated materials to the Visual AIDS archive in 2011. They contain a CD with images of artwork and accompanying image list, and an exhibition announcement. These materials are dated 2007-2012.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Darrel Ellis was born inThe Bronx in 1958 and lived and worked in New York City. He was a mixed-media artist known for his experimental approach to painting and photography.
